title: Home/Work: The Roles of Education, Literacy and Learning in the Social Networks and Mobility Patterns of Migrant Carers
abstractText:
This study is situated within the larger debate about the human geographies of skilled migration. The proposed mixed methods study focuses on professional migrant women and their mobility patterns and networks within the care industry, and in a new area of settlement - Cumbria. The aim of the study is to understand the roles of education, literacy, and learning in the women's integration into, and transformation of, the care sector, and their communities, with special attention to gender issues. Home/work encompasses:

  1. the intersection of professional migrant women's home and community lives with their work lives;
  2. the post-welfare society and its dependency on gendered, migrant care;
  3. the educational capital women bring and develop, as they migrate, and care;
  4. the hidden curriculum of workplace literacies and learning; and the
  5. the reflexive account of a migrant woman researcher studying migrant women carers in the secondary service sector.
